(60) 17 Copy No. 6 45th February, I960 -CABINETPRIVILEGES AND IMMUNITIES: EUROPEAN FREE TRADEASSOCIATIONMemorandum by the Secretary of State for Foreign AffairsArticle 35 (1) of the European Free Trade Association Convention requires that a Protocol should lay down the legal capacity, privileges and immunities to berecognised and granted by Member States in connexion with the Association.2. I propose that the scale of immunities and privileges should be as outlined in the Annex. They have been carefully considered in relation both to the precedents existing in the cases of other international organisations (particularly the specialised Agencies of the United Nations) and also to the provision of whatseems necessary to ensure the effective operation of the European Free trade association (E.F.T.A.). This would be within the limits imposed by theInternational Organisations (Immunities and Privileges) Act, 1950. An Order inCouncil would therefore be sufficient to give effect in the United Kingdom to a protocol granting such a scale.3. If this is agreed, the draft Protocol which has been submitted by the ForeignOffice to the Working Party on Privileges and Immunities of the Steering Committeeon International Organisations for their comments would be communicated to ourE.F.T.A. partners. We should then seek to secure our E.F.T.A. partners'agreement to it.S. L.Foreign Office, S.W. 1,5th February, 1960.56493 ANNEXPROTOCOL TO THE E.F.T.A. CONVENTION ON THE LEGAL CAPACITY,PRIVILEGES AND IMMUNITIES OF THE E.F.T.A.The Protocol should grant: *(i) To the E.F.T.A.:juridical personality,immunity from legal process,inviolability of premises and archives,freedom to hold or transfer funds,certain exemptions from taxation and Customs duties,freedom from censorship of its official correspondence.(ii) To the Representatives of Member States ojjany organ of the Association:immunity from arrest,inviolability of documents,the right to use codes and sealed bags,exemption from immigration restrictions,facilities in respect of currency restrictions,immunity from legal process in respect of words spoken or acts donein their official capacity.(iii) To its Officers:immunity from legal process in respect of words spoken or acts donein the course of their official duties,exemption from income tax on their official emoluments,exemption from immigration restrictions,facilities in respect of currency restrictions,repatriation facilities,free import of personal effects at the time of first taking up their posts.(iv) To the Executive Secretary:in addition to the privileges and immunities accorded to other officers,the privileges and immunities normally accorded to a diplomaticenvoy.(v) To Experts on Missions for the Association:immunity from arrest and inviolability of documents,facilities in respect of currency regulations,immunity from legal process in respect of words spoken or acts donein the course of their official duties.2. The Protocol should also include the usual provisions for the waiver ofimmunity and provision to the effect that: (i) Privileges and immunities are granted in the interests of the association and not of individuals.(ii) Member States need not grant to officers or experts on missions whoare their own nationals any privileges or immunities except immunity from legal process in respect of words spoken or written in the courseof their official duties, facilities in respect of currency restrictions,exemption from income tax on official emoluments (in the case ofofficers) inviolability of official documents (in the case of the Secretary-General and Experts)..February, 1960.
